statement.text: The great saphenous vein (GSV) is the longest vein in the body, originating from the medial marginal vein of the foot, ascending the medial leg and thigh within the saphenous compartment, and terminating at the saphenofemoral junction (SFJ) with consistent anatomic landmarks and tributary patterns essential for surgical and endovenous treatment.
statement.formal: GSV: Medial_Malleolus → Saphenous_Compartment → SFJ (2-4cm inferior to inguinal ligament, medial to femoral artery)

explanation.intuition: The GSV is like a main highway running up the inside of your leg within its own protective tunnel (saphenous compartment). Understanding its path, tributaries (on-ramps), and termination point (SFJ interchange) is essential for planning venous procedures.
explanation.key_insight: The saphenous compartment bounded by the saphenous fascia and muscular fascia is a key surgical landmark. The 'saphenous eye' on ultrasound shows the GSV within this compartment. Accessory saphenous veins run parallel and can be sources of recurrence if missed.
explanation.technical_details: The GSV originates anterior to the medial malleolus, ascends behind the medial tibial condyle, lies posteromedial in the thigh, and enters the femoral vein via the SFJ located 2-4cm below the inguinal ligament, medial to the femoral artery. Major tributaries include the anterior and posterior arch veins of the leg, posteromedial thigh vein (posterior accessory GSV), and at the SFJ: superficial inferior epigastric, superficial circumflex iliac, and external pudendal veins (the 'crosse'). The anterolateral thigh vein (anterior accessory saphenous vein) may be present.
common_misconceptions: Misconception: The GSV always follows a straight course. Reality: Anatomic variants are common; duplicated GSV occurs in 8-15% of limbs.
Misconception: Treating the GSV alone is sufficient. Reality: Accessory saphenous veins can be independent sources of reflux.
Misconception: The SFJ is at the groin crease. Reality: The SFJ is 2-4cm distal to the inguinal ligament, which is superior to the crease.

anatomic_landmarks.origin: Medial marginal vein, anterior to medial malleolus
anatomic_landmarks.leg_course: Within saphenous compartment, behind medial tibial condyle
anatomic_landmarks.sfj_relation: Medial to femoral artery, anterior to femoral vein

ultrasound_identification.saphenous_eye: GSV within hyperechoic saphenous fascia above and muscle fascia below
ultrasound_identification.location: Medial leg and thigh, superficial to deep fascia
ultrasound_identification.sfj_identification: End of GSV into common femoral vein, confirm femoral artery laterally

presentation: Visible varicose veins along GSV distribution
Symptoms worse with standing, better with elevation
Leg heaviness and aching along medial leg/thigh
Skin changes in gaiter area with advanced disease
diagnosis: Duplex ultrasound - gold standard for mapping
Identify saphenous eye to confirm GSV (not tributaries)
Measure diameter at SFJ and multiple levels
Assess reflux with Valsalva and distal compression
treatment: Preserve if suitable for arterial bypass conduit

definition.@value: The detailed anatomic course, relationships, and tributary patterns of the great saphenous vein from its origin at the medial foot to its termination at the saphenofemoral junction, essential for diagnosis and treatment of superficial venous disease.

sources.title: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy

learning_objectives: Describe the course of the GSV from origin to termination
Identify the saphenous compartment and saphenous eye on ultrasound
Name the major tributaries of the GSV at each level
Locate the SFJ relative to anatomic landmarks
clinical_pearls: The 'saphenous eye' on ultrasound confirms you're looking at the GSV, not a tributary
SFJ is 2-4cm below inguinal ligament - not at the groin crease
Accessory saphenous veins are common and can be independent sources of reflux
Always assess GSV for suitability as bypass conduit before ablation
Duplicated GSV occurs in 8-15% of limbs - map the entire vein

medicalCode.description: Asymptomatic varicose veins of unspecified lower extremity
